1.author: Electronic_Rub9385
1.body:
I’m not sure what to make of your comment.  You can’t break the laws of thermodynamics.  You can’t create energy from nothing and energy can’t be destroyed.

Two people with the exact same lifestyle will have the same body habitus. Thin people are thin because they eat less on average and expend more energy on average. Fat people expend less energy and eat more energy on average. It’s not any more complicated than that.  This is basic nutrition science and physics.

>50 years ago the US nation was very thin. Several things changed during that time: dramatic increase in food consumption (energy), dramatic increase in food availability, catastrophic decrease in energy output.  

I don’t think people realize this but we basically climb out of bed, walk 20 feet to our car, sit all day at work, walk 20 feet back to our car, sit on our couch for 4 hours, and then lay down to sleep for 8 hours. Almost zero energy is being output.

So when you combine that with the ubiquity of food you get fat people. It’s like a giant science experiment we are doing on ourselves. Transport the same fat person back to 1964 and they will be normal sized in no time.

1.author: BLYNDLUCK
1.body: There is more to biology then thermodynamics. There are plenty of sedentary people who over eat and aren’t obese. Not everyone’s metabolism is the exact same. My brother and I grew up with the same diet, did the same activities, same sports, and he has always had at least 50lbs on me. I actually probably ate more then him since he was diabetic.

1.author: Electronic_Rub9385
1.body: There might be more at play than thermodynamics but science hasn’t found it yet.

1.author: BLYNDLUCK
1.body: …yes it has. People with faster metabolisms will literally burn more calories at rest then someone with a slower metabolism. Put down your physics book and check out some biology.

1.author: Electronic_Rub9385
1.body:
Of course.  People with a higher resting metabolic rate will consume more stored energy.  People with a lower resting metabolic rate will consume less stored energy.  This is basic science.  

But it's not some mystery why fat people are fat and skinny people are skinny.  There isn't some as yet undefined biomolecular process that explains why fat people are fat and skinny people are skinny.

1.author: BLYNDLUCK
1.body: You are right, it’s not undefined. Its called the metabolism. People with a lower metabolism have a higher chance of being over weight, like you said. You have no idea what you are talking about, do you?

1.author: Electronic_Rub9385
1.body: Ah. I see. The last resort of desperate people.

3.author: StinkierPete
3.body: Asking for proof against your claim is idiotic if you don't have any evidence to support your claim

3.author: XivaKnight
3.body:
So why are you guys doing exactly that?   


This literally started with an unverified claim.   
Someone responded explaining that claim was wrong, also without evidence.   
This is called a normal conversation. I know you're a redditor that doesn't know how to disconnect from the internet, but in normal conversations, you don't need to shove a google link in someone's face every twelve seconds.   


The point of contention here is that according to you, the original claim doesn't need evidence, but for some reason to dispute the original claim, you do need evidence. This is what is known as hypocrisy and a double-standard.  


Either **both** people should be providing evidence, or neither of them need to. And demanding sources **only** from the person who refuted the original claim, instead of making the original claim, is just arrogant.

3.author: StinkierPete
3.body:
https://davemech.org/wolf-news-and-information/

This is a blog run by the scientist who first introduced the concept of alpha saying it's not real and he was wrong. If you ever want to share something proving your "scientifically proven alphas" then go ahead.

3.author: XivaKnight
3.body:
Wolves don't have alphas but many species do, which is both what I said and the person who refuted the original claim.

[https://www.silverbackgorillatours.com/gorilla/gorilla-mating-reproduction-breeding-and-courtship](https://www.silverbackgorillatours.com/gorilla/gorilla-mating-reproduction-breeding-and-courtship) Gorillas are a great example. They have more nuanced leadership than what people traditionally associate with the 'Alpha' symbol, but that doesn't change the status or leadership of a silverback. Here is another link that seems reputable: [https://gorillafund.org/uncategorized/male-hierarchy-and-a-gorilla-groups-success/](https://gorillafund.org/uncategorized/male-hierarchy-and-a-gorilla-groups-success/)

Hyenas are also notorious pack animals with distinct centralized 'alpha; leadership. [https://ideas.ted.com/everything-you-know-about-hyenas-is-wrong-these-animals-are-fierce-social-and-incredibly-smart/#:\~:text=Every%20hyena%20clan%20is%20a,for%20acceptance%2C%20food%20and%20sex.](https://gorillafund.org/uncategorized/male-hierarchy-and-a-gorilla-groups-success/) Seems a bit oddly written, but seems factual from what I scanned over.

If you don't like my links, again just google it yourself. I got these all from the first page of search results. **Your side is the one that made a claim without evidence first. Your side is the one that made a big deal about sources**. Once you get over the petty jabs and ego-tripping involved with yourself, I'd welcome any discussion you'd like, but please stop being so petulant.

EDIT: People like this loser have no validity to them. They just want to argue and complain and feel superior, which is why they will always and forever be complete losers. As for the links above; They are literally explaining the hierarchies with Gorilla and Hyenas. What definition of 'Alpha' would anyone be conceivably be using if that definition doesn't apply to the number 1 Silverback or Hyena female?

3.body: Lmao you are asking me to interpret these in such a way that it supports your claim, and then acting like they are satisfactory explanations? Good luck out there buddy, I'm going to block you

5.author: Organic-Idiocy
5.body:
>but my comment will be unpopular with the edgelords (and the very young)  

Dismissing criticism of ideas before you've even heard them suggests you're approaching the topic more emotionally than rationally.  

>compared to giving a small select few ultimate control as the core tenet?  

Capitalism is as you said an economic system.  

That some current oligarchies conflate capitalism with government, and insist that the only alternative is SOVIET RUSSIA (be very afraid people!), is a sure sign that a small percentage of very very rich people have ultimate control.  

>it's in fact the most successful and progressive economic system out there  

As you seem to agree that regulation is important, part of those regulations which are critical for avoiding the utter farce of democracy we have in the US is enforcing a mixed economy.  It's pure capitalism which is the problem.  More progressive societies use different kinds of markets more widely than we do in the US.  Some things should be vehicles for wealth like art, televisions, etc.  Things like healthcare and housing should not.  

By tying what people need to live to the whims of the ultra-wealthy you force people to choose obedience or death.  It's that simple.  

By allowing people to accumulate so much wealth they can buy politicians, and forcing politicians to depend on money to keep their jobs, and homes, etc, you at the least strongly encourage those politicians to serve the ultra rich.

5.author: Colon
5.body:
bruh - capitalism give the power to the people as its core tenet. corporate welfare (thanks to our ignorance and negligence and manipulatability) has been a downer, no question.

what's your solution to this 'nefarious evil' that is refusing to consolidate power to a few individuals with the expectation that for generations they will distribute it equally and without skimming 'pinky promise swear to god'??

say what now? i find it kinda hilarious you assume any of these people have **ideas** in addition to their misinformed complaints.

I was talking about you saying essentially that anyone who disagrees with you is a child/idiot/whatever.  

And here rather than engage with the ideas in my response, all you're doing is bashing some idea of "people who have issues with capitalism".  

Sooooo yeah: "you assume any of these people have ideas "  

I do and you just responded to them.  Have anything to say about them?

5.author: Colon
5.body:
*i'm calling them out for never having any ideas*. where are you getting the notion they have any? and keep asking me why i won't listen to their mental void? and what are your 'ideas'? you just kinda outlined some stuff that actually *supports* my argument..

they complain about capitalism (like idiots and children) cause they just recently read about the Gulf of Tonkin or MKUltra or something for the first time, and have decided all governments and economic systems are evil - and that cars, vaccines, moon landings and the internet all just appeared one day cause some peasant in a utopian bartering commune wished it into existence.

5.body:
>you just kinda outlined some stuff that actually supports my argument.

What arguments?  All you've done is trash talk people.  You haven't presented any arguments and haven't responded to what I said except to say that it "supports your arguments" lol   

There are plenty of people, like myself, who take issue with US style capitalism for legitimate reasons.

9.author: Wild_Top1515
9.body:
hmm.. i'm no geneticist.. but i'm pretty sure the issue is net gene pool diversity and cloning would actually exacerbate that issue.. but i'm also pretty sure you would have to run this experiment to know for sure how that would work..  i think you just need x number of differenet genes for it to work out.. 

i mean inbreeding actually isn't that big of a deal when it comes to defects and what not.. typically you won't have an issue for several generations.. and at that point.. yea.. crisper and genetics could definitely have a key roll in keeping us going.. but yea.. i guess you need to make sure you have at least one decent geneticist? and a lab? .. i think we should just head over to a miliary bunker.. they probably have this shit already figured out lol.

9.author: RevonQilin
9.body:
I mean as long as we dont nake too many clones and say maybe only make 3 clones from one person's dna i think it would work

Even so we def would have to rely on more natural reproduction but cloning would help us gain numbers again

Then again there are too many humans on this planet so unless our population became like 1,000 or under i think humans would be fine, the issue is other species for the most part

9.author: Wild_Top1515
9.body:
|the issue is other species for the most part

yea.. buddy lol.. bit late to worry  about that now thought isn't it? haha.. i mean i hear you.. but i'm pretty sure the reality is that there will be a mass redistribution of ecosystems that will include massive die offs(we have already seen it) but that will mean that life will just become much less diverse in the next 100-x number of years until things can balance out.. i doubt we will need to live in caves :) probably just have to move to canada and russia over the next century or whatever.. austrailia and a lot of the equator is pretty much fucked.. so unless you like watching the world burn just avoid those places.. we got geo engineering going.. it will be fine.. just don't expect to see mass migrations of cool tropical birds in the future :( won't be much of that.

10.author: Saitharar
10.body:
World: Analysis

Afghanistan: 20 years of bloodshed

'Within Taraki's wing of the party another leader, Hafizullah Amin, gained prominence. He became president in 1979 and Taraki was killed.

But it was during this time that the bloodshed began in earnest. Tens of thousands of Afghans disappeared never to be seen again.

Soviets step in

Concerned about the unsteady Communist rule in Afghanistan the Soviet Union stepped in with the full force of the Red Army in December 1979. Amin was killed and Babrak Karmal of the Parcham faction bought in to take over as president.'

Also I guess the 5 to 20 thousand people killed through an aerial bombardment by the Khalq crackdown on the Herat uprising just fell over dead spontaneously and not through the insane crackdown of the Khalq faction on suspected dissidents
The Taraki regime only controlled around 5000 of the 35000 villages in Afghanistan and tried to reclaim them bloodily and through insane state repression. How you can interpret that as no violence happening is beyond me.

10.author: Lopsided-Wrap2762
10.body:
The PDPR were already progressive with women's rights.
Soviets assassinated the PDPR leader in operation storm 333 and installed their pro soviet leader, then invaded to keep him in power.
Mujahadeens were made up of many factions. US supported some factions, Pakistan others, even china also supported.

US and other countries stopped funding by 92, but Pakistan didn't and funded one made up of young students educated in Pakistan, which eventually won against the others and became the taliban

10.author: Lopsided-Wrap2762
10.body:
There's much more educated literature than that, backed up by declassified documents.

[NSA Archive](https://nsarchive.gwu.edu/briefing-book/afghanistan-russia-programs/2019-01-29/soviet-invasion-afghanistan-1979-not-trumps-terrorists-nor-zbigs-warm-water-ports)

10.author: Lopsided-Wrap2762
10.body:
I see you added a bit more. As I said before, it was the soviet aligned Taraki led Khalqs which were brutal, as you also highlighted with the herat uprising and slaughter which happened under Taraki.
 
Honestly you are so confused, what point are you trying to make?

10.author: Saitharar
10.body:
Did you read the article?

It clearly states that the reason why the Soviet Union began to mistrust and move against Taraki and Amir was its insane internal policies and the resulting instability.

That Taraki parlayed with the Americans seeking aid after the Soviets refused him because of him being a source of the instability is just the direct result of this mistrust.
Like the only reason why Amir even went to the Americans was Because the Soviets denied bis request to intervene against the Herat uprising. Because it was insane.
Its the one where you claim no one was hurt because violence only started in december 79.

The Soviets intervened because the Khalq faction was an insane den of scorpions that destabilized their southern flank and because Amir was a loose cannon.

10.author: Saitharar
10.body: Your claim that the violence against the opposition only started after the Soviet intervention is just demonstrably false as the very same violence (eg the mass execution, disappearances and the brutal crushing of uprisings like in Herat) and the resulting loss of trust by the Soviet government was among the very reasons why the Soviets assassinated and intervened.

10.author: Lopsided-Wrap2762
10.body:
You talking about the article full of opinions without any evidence? Yeh I read it

Did you check my link which was backed up with declassified US and USSR documents?

20.body: That was a tiny part of the comment you replied to. If you're not going to have a logical argument with me, I see no reason to continue this.

20.author: broskisssss
20.body: You’re argument isn’t logical in the first place. Literally everything you said was either ridiculous or straight up anecdotal shit. Do you still not get that I’m kinda making fun of you with the whole are you a part of a criminal organization stuff?

21.author: Taint_Sampler
21.body: Some people enjoy obnoxious humor, and humor arguably makes life better (especially when there’s no direct harm or target of the joke). Next time we’re in a thread together I’ll remember to keep it professional.

21.author: LumpyJones
21.body: Good. I expect those TPS reports by close of quarter.

21.author: Taint_Sampler
21.body: Never in the history of a Reddit thread have I seen an Office Space reference, well done friend!

21.author: LumpyJones
21.body: Cute. but I wasn't even making that reference. [Those are actual things.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TPS_report) A real professional would know that.

22.body: Right but the bright side was the embalming my brother.

22.body: And how will you pay for the embalming if you don't come to work?

22.author: Rick-burp-Sanchez
22.body: How about a priest note.. I'm getting sacrificed next week anyway. Sorry, forgot to give you my two weeks'.

23.author: Vlad_the_Homeowner
23.body:
It's as close to vertical as it can get from the top down to the man, and then pretty close below that for about 4 swan-lengths before diverting to the right a bit.  The pond edge isn't perfectly straight, so it can't be perfectly vertical without digitally manipulating the image; 

Do a screen capture and line a ruler up in graphics program and see.

23.author: Jthundercleese
23.body: It's tilted counterclockwise. I saw it immediately and double checked before I commented.

23.author: Vlad_the_Homeowner
23.body: No, it isn't.  The line isn't straight - it's a pond.  It's concave to the right, so either the bottom sticks out right of center or the top does.

24.author: knoegel
24.body: Hawaii wouldn't make any difference... But Alaska... That is a beast sized state. The Japanese who landed there in WW2 found out the hard way... You don't invade the USA from Alaska.

24.author: gitwiz89
24.body: They never went to mainland alaska

24.author: knoegel
24.body: The Aleutian Islands are still part of Alaska...

24.author: gitwiz89
24.body: So the Japanese ‘found out the hard way’ that Alaska was big once they landed on a remote island which happened to be part of it?
